title: Rapid and Precise Topological Comparison with Merge Tree Neural Networks

sections.merge trees distance:
Many distances on merge trees exist:
interleaving [ref]32 , edit
distance  , functional
distortion , and the universal distance . While these distances are valuable for their
stability and
discriminatory capabilities, computing these distances often becomes impractical
due to their NP-Hard nature  0. Recent efforts aim to define more computationally feasible distances for merge trees.
For instance, the edit distance on merge trees, as discussed
in [ref]44 [ref]45, identifies the
optimal edit operations between merge trees and has been experimentally shown to be more
discriminative than both the bottleneck and one-Wasserstein 7 distances. The latter
reference [ref]45 introduced the local merge tree edit distance, specifically designed
to analyze local similarities within merge trees. Despite the work
in  demonstrating greater discriminative power than the
previously proposed edit distances for merge trees, by employing a new set of improved
edit operations, the computational cost is significantly higher, which hinders
their practical application. The interleaving distance requires an initial labeling of the
merge trees, followed by the identification of the optimal matching between the labeled merge
trees. This process, which establishes a computable metric known as the labeled
interleaving distance, is introduced in . Yan et
al.  adapted this distance for practical use and
incorporated geometric information into the labeling strategy
in .
Similarly, Curry et al. 5 employed the
Gromov–Wasserstein distance to label merge trees and compute the labeled interleaving
distance. Branch decomposition trees (BDTs) represent another method that first converts
merge trees into BDTs (i.e., transferring edges of merge trees as nodes in a new tree), and then
finds pairwise matching between these transformed
trees      .
This process adds extra computational steps, further increasing complexity. Applications utilizing merge trees distances, such as sketching 
or encoding merge trees  , primarily operate
in the original space, necessitating optimal matching between merge trees or their BDT
variants. Machine learning has been used for merge trees in the work of Pont et al. , who applied neural
networks to merge trees for compression and dimensionality reduction. Our work focuses
on fast comparison. The previous work also uses a novel but classic auto-encoder with merge trees and BDTs
as input, requiring a transformation step. In addition, their model is not designed to be
generalizable across datasets, and their use of Wasserstein distance in training
is computationally more intensive than our approach. In summary, existing work either proposes a rigorous definition of distance with
theoretical guarantees but with NP-Hard computation or describes a similarity
measure with practical applications that still require optimal matching between
merge trees. No existing work focuses on mapping merge trees into vector space for efficient
comparison. The closest approach is the work of Qin et al.  who map topological
persistence diagrams to a hash for fast comparison. Merge trees are a more expressive and
more complex topological abstraction than these diagrams. 
In our work, we utilize GNNs to map the merge trees into a vector space and
re-frame merge tree comparison as a learning task.
